_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

The Agave Dagger Draw Gas Plant is a reconditioned facility that begin operations in February 2006.  Agave Energy Company purchased the Duke Dagger Draw Gas Plant in May 2005 and combined operations with the existing Agave Gas Plant to operate as the Agave Dagger Draw Gas Plant. The facility has been successfully operating for approximately five years with no accidents to report.

The operation of the Agave Dagger Draw Gas Plant is intended to process 40 MMSCFD of gas.  The gas 
is treated to remove acid gas components, dehydrated to remove water and processed to remove 
heavy (liquid) hydrocarbons from the gas stream.  Several plant systems will be involved to perform these 
functions.  The acid gas that is removed by the amine unit will be disposed of by either acid gas injection 
into a disposal well or by incinerating in a flare.  The preferred method of disposal will be to compress the 
gas and inject it into the well.  Under emergency situations, the gas will be flared to prevent the emission 
of lethal hydrogen sulfide to atmosphere.  The cryogenic unit is designed to liquefy natural gas liquids 
from the sweet, dehydrated inlet gas by removing work (heat) from the gas be means of the turbo 
expander. The cryogenic unit recovers natural gas liquids (NGL) by cooling the gas stream to extremely 
cold temperatures (-130?F) and condensing components such as ethane, propane, butanes and heavier.  It 
is the presence of these flammable NGL that cause the facility to be subject to the OSHA PSM process 
and thus the RMP process.

The off-site consequence analysis assumed that the unit with the largest amount of NGL (cryo unit 1) had 
either a catastrophic failure (worse case scenario) or a small leak (alternative scenario).  The flammable 
material is composed of a mixture of methane, ethane, propane, butane, isobutane, pentane, and 
isopentane.  For both the worse case and alternative scenario, the mixture was assumed to be composed 
entirely of t

he chemical that would cause the worst damage, i.e. highest heat of combustion or pooling 
factor.

The Agave Dagger Draw Gas Plant is an OSHA PSM facility and as such is subject to 29 CFR 1910.119.  
In addition, the facility is subject to 29 CFR 1910.120 (HazWhoper), 29 CFR 1910.38 (EAP), 29 CFR 
1910.146 (confined spaces), 29 CFR 1910.1200 (hazard communications), 29 CFR 1910.252 (hot work), 
and 29 CFR 1910.147 (lock out/tag out).  Specific practices that are important to Agave's prevention 
program include a rigorous maintenance program, ongoing safety training, compliance audits, incident 
investigation, written operating procedures, and process hazard analysis.

Agave Energy Company has provided onsite tours of the facility to local fire and rescue departments.  
Agave has also provided such entities with a written emergency action plan.  Facility personnel are 
trained in several aspects of emergency response including the proper use of facility SCBAs, fire 
extinguishers, and H2S safety.  It is Agave's intent that regularly scheduled drills be held to ensure that 
the facility personnel are aware to the emergency action plan.  In addition, the emergency response plan 
will be reviewed semi-annually with facility personnel and appropriate changes made.  

Agave is committed to the exploration and production of oil and gas. Our corporate objectives are to 
continually increase our reserves while minimizing our costs, preventing significant impact to the 
environment, and protecting the health and safety of employees and the public.

Agave is committed to complying with all existing and relevant safety and environmental laws and 
regulations. Agave will continue to commit resources to the pursuit of fair interpretation of existing laws 
and enactment of future laws based on sound science and economic reality.

Agave continually considers new technologies, systems, and methods of organization that enhance its 
ability to achieve these business, safety and envir

onmental objectives and periodically reviews its goals to 
ensure that the needs of employees and the public are addressed.
